text: The fear of the LORD is the beginning of wisdom: a good understanding have all they that do his commandments: his praise endureth for ever.
text_kjv: The fear of the LORD is the beginning of wisdom: a good understanding have all they that do his commandments: his praise endureth for ever.
text_niv: The fear of the Lord is the beginning of wisdom;all who follow his precepts have good understanding.To him belongs eternal praise.
text_esv: The fear of the LORD is the beginning of wisdom; all those who practice it have a good understanding. His praise endures forever!
text_nlt: Fear of the LORD is the foundation of true wisdom.All who obey his commandments will grow in wisdom. Praise him forever!
text_msg: The good life begins in the fear of God—Do that and you'll know the blessing of God.His Hallelujah lasts forever!
text_nasb: The fear of the LORD is the beginning of wisdom; A good understanding have all those who do [His commandments]; His praise endures forever.
context: Psalm 111 is an acrostic psalm, meaning each verse (or pair of verses in some cases) begins with a successive letter of the Hebrew alphabet. This literary structure suggests careful composition and highlights the totality and comprehensiveness of God's attributes and deeds. The psalm reflects a deep sense of gratitude for God's redemptive actions in Israel's history, particularly the Exodus. Understanding the historical context requires recognizing the significance of the Law and the covenant relationship between God and Israel. Obedience to God's commandments was not merely a set of rules but a demonstration of loyalty and love within this covenant. The 'fear of the LORD' in this era wasn't cowering terror, but a profound respect, reverence, and awe of God's power, holiness, and justice. It acknowledged God's sovereignty and the inherent limitations of humanity. The term 'wisdom' was highly valued in ancient Israelite culture, connecting intellectual understanding with moral integrity and practical skill in navigating life. It was seen as a divine gift, accessible through relationship with God and adherence to his ways. The psalm was likely used in liturgical settings, sung during festivals and communal worship, reinforcing the community's commitment to God's law and praise. The connection between fearing God, understanding his commandments, and offering him praise underscores the holistic nature of Israelite faith.
meaning: Theologically, Psalm 111:10 establishes a crucial principle: the 'fear of the LORD' is the 'beginning of wisdom.' This implies that true wisdom doesn't originate from human intellect alone, but from recognizing and submitting to God's authority. It's not just intellectual assent to God's existence, but a posture of humility and reverence that shapes one's thinking and actions. This fear is the foundation upon which all true knowledge and understanding are built. The phrase 'a good understanding have all they that do his commandments' suggests that obedience is not merely an outward act, but an inward transformation that leads to greater insight and discernment. The act of keeping God's commandments opens the heart and mind to a deeper comprehension of his character and purposes. This verse emphasizes the inseparable link between knowing God and obeying him. Obedience is not a burden but a pathway to wisdom. It clarifies that moral behavior rooted in faith is not arbitrary but divinely ordained. God's commandments are not arbitrary rules, but expressions of his love and justice, designed to guide humanity towards flourishing. Finally, the affirmation that 'his praise endureth for ever' highlights the ultimate aim of wisdom and obedience: to glorify God. Praising God isn't just an occasional act but an ongoing response to his goodness and faithfulness, reflecting the enduring nature of his character and his covenant with his people.
application: In contemporary life, Psalm 111:10 challenges us to re-evaluate our understanding of wisdom and success. In a culture often obsessed with individual achievement and worldly knowledge, this verse reminds us that true wisdom begins with acknowledging God's authority and submitting to his will. Practically, this means making choices that reflect God's values, even when they are unpopular or inconvenient. It requires us to cultivate a daily practice of seeking God's guidance through prayer, scripture reading, and meditation. To 'fear the Lord' in modern terms means to cultivate a healthy respect for God, recognizing his holiness and justice, and allowing that reverence to shape our decisions. It means choosing ethical behavior in business, treating others with kindness and compassion, and standing up for justice, even when it's difficult. It necessitates aligning our actions with God's commandments, as reflected in the Bible. It means evaluating our priorities, ensuring that our pursuit of success doesn't compromise our integrity or our relationship with God. Moreover, this verse calls us to cultivate a spirit of praise and gratitude. Recognizing God's blessings and acknowledging his faithfulness in our lives should be a constant refrain in our hearts. This can manifest in various ways: through prayer, worship, acts of service, and sharing our faith with others. It also means fostering a continuous learning journey, integrating our faith with our education, career, and relationships. This holistic approach enables us to live lives that honor God and reflect his wisdom in all that we do, resisting the allure of worldly success at the expense of our spiritual well-being. Regularly ask yourself: How can I act with greater reverence to God in my workplace/home/community?
prayer: Heavenly Father, instill within me a true fear of the Lord, a deep reverence for your holiness and your unwavering justice. May this reverence be the foundation upon which I build my life, guiding my decisions and shaping my character. Grant me the understanding to grasp your commandments, not just as rules to be followed, but as pathways to wisdom and flourishing. Help me to align my actions with your will, seeking your guidance in all that I do. Open my heart to recognize your blessings and to offer you ceaseless praise for your goodness and faithfulness. May my life be a testament to your enduring glory, a reflection of your wisdom, and an offering of unending praise. In Jesus’ name, Amen.

faqs.answer: The 'fear of the Lord' is not terror, but profound respect, reverence, and awe for God's power, holiness, and justice. It's acknowledging his sovereignty and seeking to live in accordance with his will, motivated by love and gratitude.
faqs.question: Q1 about this verse: What does 'fear of the Lord' really mean?

faqs.answer: Wisdom, as linked to the 'fear of the Lord,' isn't merely intellectual knowledge, but practical discernment, moral integrity, and the ability to make wise decisions rooted in God's principles. It's applied knowledge guided by faith.
faqs.question: Q2: How is 'wisdom' defined in relation to fearing the Lord?

faqs.answer: Obedience opens the heart and mind to a deeper understanding of God's character and purposes. By following his commandments, we experience the benefits of his wisdom and gain insight into his ways.
faqs.question: Q3: How does obedience to God's commandments lead to 'good understanding'?

faqs.answer: God's praise endures forever because his character, goodness, and faithfulness are eternal. Our praise is a response to his unchanging nature and a reflection of his everlasting glory.
faqs.question: Q4: Why is praising God considered to 'endure forever'?

faqs.answer: Cultivate the 'fear of the Lord' through prayer, Bible study, meditation, and reflecting on God's character. Seek his guidance in your decisions and strive to live according to his commandments, motivated by love and reverence.
faqs.question: Q5: How can I cultivate the 'fear of the Lord' in my daily life?
